Optimal Population and Capital
over Time: The Maximin
Perspective

GUILLERMO A. CALVO
Columbia University

INTRODUCTION

A well-known implication of the Solow-Swan growth model with non-overlapping gener-
ations is that if individuals do not care about the number or well-being of their descendants,
the present generation will gain nothing from having children (see Phelps (1966)). The
non-overlapping assumption is quite crucial for such a result. Consider instead the case
where generations overlap in Samuelson-Diamond fashion (Diamond (1965)), i.e. indi-
viduals live for two periods—they work in the first and retire in the second. At present,
period zero, there are, therefore, two generations alive, one of which is old and the other
which is young and will survive until the end of the next period. Again, the old at time
zero do not, in principle, benefit from future generations but that is no longer true for the
young at time zero because their capital will be operated by the young in period one. In
a competitive environment, for instance, with no childbearing costs and positive cross-
partial derivatives between capital and labour, the utility of the young at time zero never
decreases by adding one more member to generation 1, i.e. the set of individuals born in
period one, because ceteris paribus the rate of return on capital in period one also goes up.

It is clear that we must adopt some allocation rule in order to be able to be more
specific about the number of children that present generations must have if they want to
maximize their utility. In this paper I will examine the case where present and future
generations are constrained to be *' fair ", in the sense of the Rawlsian maximin, to every
individual who lives or is going to live during any subinterval of the planning period (stretch-
ing from zero to the indefinite future) under the assumption that it is possible to allocate
consumpdüon freely among individuals subject only to the technological constraints.
Consequently, we are going to be looking at a typical problem of a central planning agency
when its objective is to maximize the welfare of present generations but it is constrained to
abide by the dictates of the maximin principle.

The present approach, with its emphasis on the welfare of the living generations, is
by no means typical of the optimal population literature, most of which is instead con-
cerned with the maximization of a sum of utilities (see, e.g. Meade (1955), Dasgupta (1969,
1974), Pitchford (1972)). This objective may very well imply sacrificing present generations'
utilities in favour of the future ones. Consider, for instance, the Meade-Dasgupta maxi-
mand (see Meade (1955), Dasgupta (1969)), consisting of a discounted or undiscounted
sum of utilities weighted by the number of individuals in each generation. As shown by
Dasgupta (1969), it is possible to find conditions under which, in the Solow-Swan model
with non-overlapping generations, it would be optimal (according to his criterion) to have
positive population at every point in time, implying that present generations would have to
refrain from consuming all the available capital. Therefore, in a Dasgupta optimal plan
the present generation is worse off than it would be if it had no descendants and ate up all

1:
Notes and Comments
The Political Business Cycle: A Complementary
Study

ULRICH LAÁCHLER
Columbia University
The dynamics of politically induced business cycles have recently been explored by W. D.
Nordhaus [2] in the context of a Phillips curve framework. It is my contention that his
results are extremely sensitive to the nature of the loops around that curve. A specific
model will be provided in support of my argument, as well as a diagrammatic outline. I
will conclude with some brief empirical observations.
]--vuf
1

The central result of Nordhaus' analysis is that a myopic vote-maximizing government will
attain a steady-state position of higher inflation and lower unemployment than is the
** social optimum ", Nordhaus [2, p. 180]. This result will be shown to be reversed when
the same government is operating within a Phillips curve framework that generates counter-
clockwise cycles in the inflation/unemployment plane.

We may recall that the cyclical behaviour of the inflation/unemployment rates observed
by A. W. Phillips [3] for pre-1957 Great Britain tended to be in a counterclockwise direction
around the average relationship. The United States, during that same period, bears witness
to a roughly similar experience, although somewhat less pronounced. In more recent work,
H. I. Grossman [1] maintains that, in the post-World War II period, the cyclical movement
of inflation and unemployment seems to have been reversed. A quick glance at the
American data will support this observation, in particular for the post-1954 period.

In view of these observations, I would like to develop a general macroeconomic
framework which can take account of both types of cyclical movements. The structure of
this framework consists of the following equations:

A Note on Conjectural Equilibria

DOUGLAS GALE
University of Cambridge

This note is a gloss on a paper by F. Hahn (1978). There is nothing really new here except
the method of proving the two main results: existence of a non-Walrasian conjectural
equilibrium and impossibility of rational conjectural equilibrium (in Hahn's sense). A great
deal of use is made of the fact that competitive behaviour is a special case of conjectural
behaviour and this helps draw out the connection between conjectural equilibria and
W-equilibria.

University of Rochester

1:
The Effect of State and Private
Pensions on Retirement Behaviour
and Personal Capital Accumulation

R. C L. HEMMING
Brunel University
1l. INTRODUCTION

Feldstein [1] has suggested recently that the growth of social security pension schemes has
a dual impact on personal savings. Firstly, there is a savings replacement effect which
leads to a reduction in personal savings and, secondly, an induced retirement effect which
leads to an increase in savings which has to be spread over a longer retirement period.
It is argued that as a scheme becomes more established the induced retirement effect
diminishes. This implies that when one comes to consider the effect of changes in pension
benefits and contributions with a well-developed scheme the savings replacement effect
operates almost in isolation.

In this paper a private pension scheme is introduced from which the individual can
receive a pension some years before he becomes eligible to receive the state pension. It is
shown that it is then possible for both the growth of the private scheme and changes in
state and private pension contributions and benefits to have an effect on savings determined
by the savings replacement and induced retirement effects.

2. INDIVIDUAL RETIREMENT BEHAVIOUR

It is assumed that an individual lives for L years and is retired from period 7, a date which
he is free to choose. If he is retired on or after period 7, he receives the state pension at a
flat rate p. The private pension is organized through a terminal salary scheme whereby the
individual contributes a constant proportion o, 0««« 1, of his wage income w(7) into the
scheme in return for a pension f(T)w(T), 0 «f «1, in every period of retirement, the earliest
possible date of receipt being 7; « T,. The scale of benefits, as given by fi(.), is a function
of the retirement date. An individual who retires before he is eligible for the state pension
will still receive it from 73.
In addition the following assumptions are made:

(Al) all income and price variables are known with certainty;
(A2) there is a perfect capital market ;
(A3) terminal bequests are fixed and can therefore be ignored;

(A4) the individual's intertemporal utility function depends only on the intertemporal
consumption stream: utility is an increasing function of consumption expendi-
ture in any one period and consumption expenditure in each period is a normal
good, increasing as total lifetime income increases.

The individual's problem is to choose an optimal retirement date. 'The above assump-
tions imply that it will be that value of 7' which maximizes the discounted present value of
lifetime income.

1:
dist dind

-
On Competitive Prices in a Multi-
Sector Economy with Stochastic
Production and Resources
ITZHAK. ZILCHA
Hebrew University and University of Illinois
1. INTRODUCTION

One of the central aims in the theory of economic growth is to characterize optimal paths
by a system of competitive or efficiency prices.

We work in a multi-sector economy with production and consumption over time.
Our model is a generalization of Radner's model [16] similar to that presented by Dana [4].

A. central planner has to decide how to divide the available commodities, at each period,
between consumption and production according to some criterion of optimality. The
planner may face uncertainty about technological progress in future, natural resources and
their locations, labour, etc. In this work we assume (as in [4], [16], that there is uncertainty
about the production possibilities and the (exogenous) supply of resources which are
essential to production. Uncertainty, at each period, is represented by the occurrence of
some *' state of the environment " which is independent of the planner's decisions; these
uncertainties arise similarly in successive planning periods. The sequence of ** states " is
represented by a stochastic process on some probability space, where the probability
distribution on the set of sequences of '*'states" is known completely. "This is more
general than considering a sequence of independent identically distributed random variables
(as in [3], [10]) or a stationary Markov process in which the transition probability is given
(as in [15], [7]).

The evaluation of feasible programmes is done by a generalization of Gale's ** catching-
up " criterion (see [6]), namely, we maximize the expected sum of non-discounted utilities.
This criterion is sensitive to an increment of utility at any period and gives equal treatment
to all periods.

Suppose that a certain programme is optimal according to the planner's evaluation.
Is there a price system such that in this programme producers maximize their profits and
consumers maximize their utility? We prove that each optimal programme can be sustained
by prices (which are integrable functions) such that at each date: (a) at almost all ** states "",
the optimal production maximizes the expected intertemporal profit; (b) the optimal
consumption, almost surely, minimizes the ** cost " among all consumption vectors yielding
no less utility. Moreover, these prices are also Malinvaud prices for the optimal programme
(see [9]), i.e. the terminal cost minimization conditions are satisfied. To prove this result
we define valuation functions and use dynamical programming methods.
2. PRESENTATION OF THE MODEL AND THE MAIN RESULTS

We shall present the multi-sector economic model which is basically a generalization of
Radner's stationary model in [16], similar to that introduced by Dana [4].
Uncertainty is represented by a random *' state of the environment " at each date,

affiliations.found:
Money, Expectations and the
Existence of a Temporary
Equilibrium

BRYCE HOOL
University of Wisconsin, Madison

ROBERT P. PARKS
Washington University

Arrow's impossibility theorem (Arrow [1]) shows that a social welfare function (which
specifies a transitive complete ordering on social alternatives for each m-tuple of individual
preferences) is necessarily dictatorial if it has an unlimited domain (all possible m-tuples of
preferences), is independent of irrelevant alternatives, Pareto consistent and there are at
least three alternatives. It is shown here that such a social welfare function must be dicta-
torial even if there is only one m-tuple of preferences in the domain if it is neutral, Pareto
consistent and there are enough alternatives so that in one m-tuple of preferences there is
diversity of preference among the alternatives. Although Arrow did not require neutrality,
it is a logical consequence of his conditions.

In the second section we argue that this result shows that the Bergson-Samuelson
welfare function is dictatorial. Samuelson [7] and Plott [5] argue that the Arrow theorem
really has nothing to do with the Bergson problem since Bergson assumes that the preferences
of the society are fixed. In fact, Samuelson argues that there are as many Bergson functions
as there are r-tuples of preferences in the domain of Arrow's function, and hence the
impossibility theorem has nothing to do with Bergson's welfare function. The result here,
though, is shown for a fixed m-tuple of preferences and so can be applied to the Bergson
concept.

GEORGES BORDES
University of Bordeaux 1
Laboratoire d' Analyse et de Recherche économique

1:
Social Choice and Parties
K..G. BINMORE
London School of Economics
1. INTRODUCTION

An important hypothesis for Arrow's Impossibility Theorem is that any configuration of
personal preferences on the part of the individuals involved must be allowed. In this paper
a similar paradox is obtained under a weaker hypothesis. The set of individuals is supposed
to be partitioned into disjoint ** parties " characterized by the fact that no two members of
the same party may express opposing strong preferences over any pair of alternatives. A
simple graphical technique is employed which avoids the necessity for lengthy mathematical
exposition.

Implications of the result for social choice mechanisms in which *'intensities of
preference " are admissible are not explored in this paper.
2. FORMALITIES

Following Arrow [1], we consider a set of 7 individuals (labelled 1, 2, ..., ») who each sub-
scribe to a preference relation over a set S of alternatives. Each individual preference
relation R; is supposed to be * rational" in the sense that it is reflexive, transitive and
complete. (For this and other terminology, see Sen [2].) The set of all rational preference
relations will be denoted by £P.

We consider functions f which are defined on a subset of A" and whose values

This will be referred to as condition (U). Also natural is the condition

The condition of the ** Independence of Irrelevant Alternatives "' (T) asserts that the

collective preference over a pair (x, y] of alternatives is independent of the individual
preferences over pairs other than (x, y). (For a full account, see Sen [2].)

1:
The Political Business Cycle: A Comment

BRUNO $. FREY and HANS-JÜRGEN RAMSER
University of Constance
Nordhaus' recent paper in this Review [1] is of particular interest as it offers an explicit
analysis of the interaction between the economy and the polity, albeit for a partial section
of the economy only. It analyses both the steady-state equilibrium and the disequilibrium
paths within electoral periods. This comment is directed to the first part only, where the
long-run choice in democratic systems over the course of many electoral periods is studied.
Nordhaus reaches the ** fundamental long-run result " that:

** 'The democratic outcome corresponds to the policy which was found . . . to be purely
myopic. That is, it comes at the point where the implicit rate of time preference is
infinite " [1, p. 179].

This implies that a democratic government chooses a point on the long-run Phillips-curve
that has lower unemployment and higher inflation than optimal.

This comment is intended to show that Nordhaus' result is not an attribute of a
democratic government as such, but rather depends on the specific assumptions made
about the government's utility function. If another—equally plausible—utility function
is used, quite different results follow. Using the same assumptions about voters evaluations
of unemployment and inflation and about the trade-off between the two, it turns out that
unemployment is always higher, and inflation correspondingly lower, than Nordhaus
suggests to be typical for a democracy.

The economic model is unchanged, but instead of the goal of vote-maximization
[1, p. 174] it is assumed that a government wants to maximize the length of time which it
can expect to remain uninterruptedly in power. It seems plausible that government poli-
ticians are not only interested in winning the next election but do in fact look beyond it,
especially if they are confident of winning the forthcoming election. The younger party
members will exert particular pressure in this direction as they are interested in ensuring
that their party is still popular with the voters in the future, when they have a chance to
take over governmental jobs.!

To formalize this idea, the aggregate voting function g,(—u, —7) may be interpreted
as the government's probability of election (or re-election) in period n (0 € g,«1). A
government may stay in power over periods ? — 1, 2, ..., oo. The probability of being in
power in period 1 and not being elected in period 2 is g,(1 —92); the probability of being in
power both in period 1 and 2, but of being defeated in period 3 is g,:g;,(1—93), etc. In
general, the probability of being in power uninterruptedly over n periods and of being
defeated in period n--1 is II1g,(1—9,,,). The expected length of time in power is the
sum of the various periods of being in government, weighted by the above probability

o0 t
$ 11-942 II 2- (1)
t—-1 T—-1

This expression may also be derived by assuming a discrete utility function taking the
value one if the party is in power, and zero otherwise. The expected utility of n uninterrupted
periods in government is n(1—9,,,)II1g,. The sum of expected utilities over all possible
government periods is equation (1). Using the assumption that a democratic government

Social Choice and Individual
Rankings II "*

B. FINE
Birkbeck College

and

K. FINE
University of Edinburgh

In Part I of this paper [2] it was shown that certain appealing conditions forced any social
quasi-ordering rule to include the positional rule, which is itself the intersection of all
finite ranking (f.r. rules. These conditions are slightly strengthened in the first three
sections of this part, but this allows us to characterize in Section 3 the rules that also
satisfy the additional properties as the intersection of some set of f.r. rules. In case a con-
tinuity property, which can be interpreted as a non-veto condition applied to groups, does
not hold, the set of f.r. rules must be extended to include transfinite weightings. Section 1
finds sufficient conditions for a quasi-ordering rule to be positional. This is used in Section
2 to prove the results contained in Section 3 for the special case of a social ordering rule,
when a single f.r. rule emerges. This special case is then generalized in Section 3.

In Section 4, for the first time in the paper, we analyse conditions that recognize
social decision depending upon the number of alternatives. Previously, only the number
of individuals has been effectively allowed to vary. Again, simple and natural properties
have powerful consequences, and it is thereby shown that the Borda rule is a compelling
choice for making social decision, given a veil of ignorance, that is no knowledge of the
special features of the individuals and alternatives concerned. Incase only a quasi-ordering
rule is required, social decision is based on the intersection of a set of f.r. rules symmetrical
about the Borda rule.

In Section 5 we turn to choice structure rules. First a positional choice structure is
defined. It is the strongest such rule containing all the f.r. rules, since an alternative in a
set belongs to the choice from that set iff for some f.r. it is best in the set. This last condi-
tion is shown to be equivalent to demanding that the HC of that element does not belong
to the convex hull of the HC of the other alternatives in the set. Then an outline is made
for a conditions analysis of the rule: it is found to be the weakest rule satisfying certain
conditions, in the sense that any other rule satisfying those conditions must be more
decisive. In this, the method, results and analysis correspond to Part I's consideration
of the positional quasi-ordering rule.

Section 6 is devoted to an examination of some questions concerned with the in-
dependence of conditions and Section 7 contains concluding remarks. The above only
sketches the major results of this paper. In addition, the analysis of normal social quasi-
ordering rules in Section 2 and Section 3 has obvious relevance to the theory of production
and utility under risk in the presence of indivisibility.

Finally, it should be noted that throughout this part, individual preferences are assumed
to be antisymmetrical. Whilst the complications posed by individual indifference were

have contributed to all sections of the paper, though the first has contributed more to the material on the
positional rule and the second to the material on normal social rules. Some of the results for ordering
rules in this paper have been independently established by Smith [12].

Inefficiency and the Demand for
"* Money" in a Sequence Economy "'

DAVID STARRETT
Harvard University

Several authors have recently attempted to incorporate transactions costs and/or incomplete
information into models of general equilibrium (see, for example, Foley [3], Radner [7]
and Starr [9]). Of particular interest to us here is the model of Professor Hahn [4]. His
model has the following properties (among others).

1. Perfect certainty; in particular, prices on all markets (both spot and future) are
known for sure by all agents at the outset.

2. Convexity in the transactions technology; in the presentation transaction opera-
tions essentially take the place of production operations as there is no independent
production sector.

A. model with these properties seems, at first glance, to be isomorphic to another in
which *'sold " goods and ** bought" goods are different commodities, and there is a
production technology for transforming the one into the other. In such a model we would
surely expect that if efficiency is defined relative to the transactions technology, then a
competitive equilibrium would be efficient (all the assumptions of the standard theory
would seem to be satisfied).

However, Professor Hahn argued that competitive efficiency (in the sense defined
above) was highly unlikely. The argument was persuasive, but not completely convincing,
since no actual examples of inefficiency were given. In this paper we seek first to elucidate
the inefficiency by example. Having done so, we discover that the inefficiency can provide
a rational demand for a certain type of money. For ease of exposition, the analysis is
carried out entirely by example in Part I. À general treatment is deferred until Part II.

A Dynamic Model of Firm Entry: Comment"*
KOH OKUGUCHI
Yokohama City University, Japan
Extending Quandt and Howrey's analysis of firm entry, Myers and Weintraub [1] proved
local stability of the equilibrium pair of number of firms and labour hire. This note is
intended to derive conditions for global stability of the equilibrium in Myers-Weintraub
model.

We adopt Myers-Weintraub's notation for which the reader is referred to [1]. Labour

1:
On the Stability of
Generalized Metzlerian Systems "'
MICHIHIRO OHYAMA
Keio University
I. INTRODUCTION

The study of competitive equilibrium has always been concerned with the *' stability
of that price structure which clears the commodity market. The earlier economists defined
the concept of stability, and tended to assume it without giving a rigorous analysis of the
stability hypothesis. Hicks [8] presented well-known conditions for stability, but in so
doing failed to consider the dynamic process of price adjustment through time. None-
theless, in a classic paper Metzler [12] pointed out that if all commodities are gross
substitutes, the Hicksian conditions for perfect stability are identical to the conditions for
stability in a dynamic sense. This discovery, brilliant as it was, turned out to be only a
prelude to a more exciting theme. In later developments, it was established by Negishi

15], Hahn [7], Arrow and Hurwicz [2], and Arrow, Block and Hurwicz [1] that a com-
petitive equilibrium is indeed dynamically stable for a gross substitute economy.

Despite the central place it occupies, the assumption of gross substitutability represents
a serious drawback to the stability literature. Although we can certainly dispose of com-
plementarity of a technical nature often observed among several commodities by a simple
process of aggregation, it is impossible to assume away weak gross complements without
loss of generality. It should be noted, however, that the absence of gross complements
is by no means a necessary condition for dynamic stability. Thus, the difficulty associated
with universal gross substitutability should not totally undermine the stability hypothesis.
This point, well recognized in the literature, is of course of little interest unless one is able
to identify meaningful classes of competitive systems in which both complementarity and
stability are present. This paper attempts to proceed a few steps forward in this direction
via the natural route of extending the Metzlerian gross substitute system.

We shall first propose three distinct, but closely related generalizations of the
Metzlerian system. Subsequently, in Section III, these generalized systems will be shown
to be locally stable even though they may include elements of gross complementarity.
To indicate the extent to which the Metzler theorem carries through, we shall also demon-
strate that the Hicksian conditions are necessarily satisfied for a particular pair of these
generalized systems. From this, we can directly proceed to comparative statics. In
Section IV we shall present a result of comparative statics closely analogous to the one
obtainable for the original Metzlerian system. This result, far stronger than the one
implied by the Hicksian conditions, will be seen to hold for a (different) pair of the proposed
generalizations. To illustrate the nature of our concepts, a numerical example will then
be considered briefly. Finally, in Section V, we shall discuss some related literature,
especially an alternative line of generalization suggested by Morishima [13], [14].

1 First version received November 1970; final version received October 1971 (Eds.).

2 'This paper is taken from my Ph.D. thesis submitted to the University of Rochester in February
1972. Iam indebted to Professor Lionel W. McKenzie for valuable criticism and encouragement. I also
wish to thank Professors James P. Quirk, Kazunori Yokoyama, and Mr Anjan Mukherjee for helpful
discussions. Mr Frank D. Lewis kindly helped me make the manuscript more readable.
